Rule.desc: Local variables should not use the same names as member variables
Parameters should not use the same names as member variables
Do not declare the size of an array when the array is passed into a function as a parameter
Do not define constants via #define
Shift and bitwise operations should not be performed on operands of essentially signed or enum type
The value of an expression shall not be assigned to an object with a narrower essential type
Do not use a #define that prevents the compiler from checking types except ones used only in #ifs and #elifs conditions
Do not use a #define that prevents the compiler from checking types
If a pointer to a structure or union is never dereferenced within a translation unit, then the implementation of the object should be hidden
Avoid switch statements with only one case
Constructors allowing for conversion should be made explicit
Do not use user-defined conversion functions
The first operand of a conditional-operator shall have type bool
Declare at least one constructor to prevent the compiler from doing so
Have assignment operator returns a reference to *this; make assignment operator's return type a non-const reference to it's class' type
Bitwise operators, comparison operators, logical operators, comma operator should be const
Postfix increment and decrement should be implemented in terms of their prefix counterparts
Avoid overloading logical operators AND, OR (&&, ||)
Prefer C++-style casts
If you'd like to support mixed-mode operations make operators a non-member functions
Prefer non-member operators than member ones to support mixed-mode arithmetic
Avoid dynamic_casts
Conversion operator, operator->, operator(), operator[] should be const
Declare reference parameters as const references whenever possible
Have the non-const version call the const version of member function instead of duplicating the const version definition
Do not define inline functions in source files
Consider using the natural relationship between the assignment version of an operator and the stand-alone version
Declare parameters or local variable as const whenever possible
Member functions shall be declared const whenever possible
Const member functions shall not return non-const pointers or references to class-data
Avoid overloading comma operator ","
Classes which have only getters/setters (accessors/mutators) are not allowed
Prefer iostream.h to stdio.h
Avoid returning handles to class data from member functions
User-conversion cast operators should be made explicit
Prefer alias declarations to typedefs
Prefer Scoped Enums to Unscoped Enums
Declare overriding functions with 'override' specifier
Declare copy constructor and copy assignment operators with the 'delete' specifier to prevent copying of class
Declare copy constructor and copy assignment operators with the 'delete' specifier instead of using a base class with private methods to prevent copying of class
Prefer 'nullptr' over 'NULL' or '0'(zero)
Never allow an exception to be thrown from a destructor, deallocation, and swap
Throw by value, catch by reference
Do not throw from within destructor
Do not initialize a reference to an object whose address can be changed
All member variables should be initialized in constructor
Initialize static class members
An assignment operator shall assign all data members
List members in an initialization list in the order in which they are declared
Avoid initialization order problems across translation units by replacing non-local static objects with local static objects
Do not assume that members are initialized in any special order in constructors
Prefer initialization to assignment in constructors
All automatic variables shall have been assigned a value before being used
Assignment operators shall not be used in expressions that yield a Boolean value
Floating-point expressions shall not be tested for equality or inequality
The controlling expression of a for statement shall not contain any objects of floating type
A pointer parameter in a function prototype should be declared as pointer to const if the pointer is not used to modify the addressed object
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
A function should be used in preference to a function-like macro
Protected member functions shall not return non-const handles to class-data
Public member functions shall not return non-const handles to class-data
Use the same form in corresponding calls to new/malloc and delete/free
Do not invoke malloc/realloc for objects having constructors
Avoid hiding the global new
Declare a copy assignment operator for classes with dynamically allocated memory
Declare a copy constructor for classes with dynamically allocated memory
Never return a dereferenced local pointer initialized by new in this function scope
Call delete on pointer members in destructors
A copy constructor shall copy all data members and bases
An assignment operator shall assign all data bases
Adhere to convention when writing new and delete
Adhere to convention when writing new
If a class defines any overload of operator new, it should provide overloads of all three of plain, in-place, and non-throwing operator new
If a class defines any overload of operator new[], it should provide overloads of all three of plain, in-place, and non-throwing operator new[]
If a class defines any overload of operator delete, it should provide overloads of all three of plain, in-place, and non-throwing operator delete
If a class defines any overload of operator delete[], it should provide overloads of all three of plain, in-place, and non-throwing operator delete[]
Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later
Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later
Do not allocate memory and expect that someone else will deallocate it later
Use objects to manage resources
Use objects to manage resources
Write operator delete if you write operator new
Write operator delete[] if you write operator new[]
Always provide new and delete together
Always provide new[] and delete[] together
Freed memory shouldn't be accessed under any circumstances
Destructor should not be called manually
Never provide brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating non-arrays
Always provide empty brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating arrays
Both copy constructor and copy assignment operator should be declared for classes with a nontrivial destructor
Do not use calloc, malloc, realloc and free functions
A copy constructor and a copy assignment operator shall be declared for classes that contain pointers to data items or nontrivial destructors
Class cannot inherit other class more than once unless it is virtual inheritance
Be wary about using multiple inheritance of classes that are not abstract interfaces
Do not directly access global data from a constructor
Avoid calling virtual functions from constructors
Define a virtual destructor in classes used as base classes which have virtual functions
Make destructors virtual in base classes
A pointer to an abstract class shall not be converted to a pointer of a class that inherits from that abstract class
Make base class destructors public and virtual, or protected and nonvirtual
If a class destructor is called and the class has virtual functions it shall have a virtual destructor
Casts from a base class to a derived class should not be performed on polymorphic types
Avoid "public" data members
Avoid 'protected' data members
If a class has virtual functions it shall have a virtual destructor
Down casting (casting from base to derived class) shall not be allowed
Do not derive functions with the same name from more than one base class
For multiple inheritance use virtual common base class
Avoid using the friend mechanism
Protected member function shall not return non-const handles to private class-data
Do not redefine an inherited virtual function with a different default parameter value
Avoid declaring virtual functions inline
Declare copy assignment operator for class with reference or const members
Never redefine an inherited nonvirtual function
Do not redefine an inherited nonvirtual function with template parameter
Public member functions shall not return non-const handles to private/protected class-data
Member functions declared in derived class should not hide functions declared in base classes
Write a using declaration to redeclare overloaded functions
Check for assignment to self in operator=
Consider use composition instead of private inheritance
Prefer composition when don't need inheritance
Do not use multiple inheritance
Eliminate unused parameters
Prefer "a @= b" than "a = a @ b", where "@" is +, -, *, /, %
Prefer "a @= b" than "a = a @ b", where "@" is &, |, ^, <<, >>
Pass objects by reference instead of by value
Global function containing recursion, loops or virtual function call should not be inlined
Member function containing recursion or loops should not be inlined
Consider using op= instead of stand-alone op
Postpone variable definitions as long as possible
Every switch statement shall have at least two switch-clauses
Avoid unused local variables
Trivial accessor and mutator functions should be inlined
Trivial forwarding functions should be inlined
Remove unnecessary '== true'
Consider returning object by reference instead of by value
Declare member variables in the descending size order
Do not call delete on non-pointers
Properly terminate character strings
The class object should be passed by reference if the class has non-static pointers and has no declared copy constructor
Operators should not return value by reference
A string literal shall not be modified
Don't treat arrays polymorphically
Avoid overloading class methods on a pointer and a numerical type
Do not create inline non-member functions that contain local static data
An element of an object shall not be initialized more than once
Use mechanism that prevents multiple inclusion of the file i.e. include guards or "#pragma once" preprocessor directive
Don't use hard coded value of offset in structures
Never use gets()
When calling swap, employ a using declaration for std::swap, then call swap without namespace qualification
Do not declare the non-member to be an overloading of std::swap
Member version of swap should never throw exceptions
Use vector and string instead of arrays
Define non-member functions inside templates when type conversions are desired
In template global functions use 'typename' to identify nested dependent type names
In template classes use 'typename' to identify nested dependent type names
